body:
I think this is intended behaviour, at least according to [the documentation](http://www.glfw.org/docs/latest/input_guide.html#joystick)?

(emphasis mine)
> Joystick state **is updated as needed when a joystick function is called** and does not require a window to be created or glfwPollEvents or glfwWaitEvents to be called.

Maybe adding this information to the _Joystick configuration changes_ section would make this harder to miss.

@FlandreScarlet Agreed, the documentation needs to be clarified.

@gestaltdevstudio ~~What other functions were you expecting would trigger this event?~~ Sorry, it was in the title. Callback setters _never_ trigger events, though. Were there any other functions? I'm looking into making this bit more consistent between platforms, so this is great timing.

rename.from: glfwSetJoystickCallback doesn't trigger GLFW_DISCONNECTED on linux

body: @gestaltdevstudio GLFW can't call your callback function unless you first pass control to it by calling one of its functions. If not one of the joystick functions, which other ones should also check for joystick disconnection?

@elmindreda This is a good question. Maybe calling pollJoystickEvents in glfwPollEvents() instead of glfwGetJoystickAxes or glfwGetJoystickButtons. I think it will be more faithful with the callback behavior. If a joystick connected has to be used why not to check if it's present always? Even if I'm not reading it's axes and buttons?

I hope I have helped :)

I can do device connection events that way. Not sure about disconnection.

Out of curiosity, what are you using the disconnection events from joysticks you aren't polling for?

@elmindreda I am testing and adapting my own engine to use GLFW, and I do it bit by bit, until it runs on Linux / Win. So first I created the callback function and I was sure that the callback should work entirely just with glfwPollEvents(), before I test the joytick's buttons and axes.
It was more intuitive for me. And I was hoping for a more simple function to check the connectivity than one that get all axes or buttons. Besides getting the GLFW_CONNECTED without all that.

But it's just my way of thinking. Do you think it makes sense? I don't know if I was clear...
Thanks for all of your hard working!
Let me know if I can help.

PS: I thought that was an issue on linux at the beginning ahahaha
